proof:
Let us consider an arbitrary configuration $F$ that belongs to the set $B_0$. To begin, we recall from the proof of Lemma 51 that for any sufficiently large $d$, the graph $G$ satisfies with high probability that $c(F) \le 1 + \eta n$ for any ordered configuration $F$. We will denote by $S$ the set of vertices that are in the non-giant components of the graph $(V_c, F)$.
We will now establish an upper bound for the ratio $w_c(F)/Z_c^{\mathrm{ord}}$ by analyzing different cases. Let us examine the case where $c(F) - 1 \le |S| \le \eta n/2$. In this situation, by utilizing the lower bound $Z_c^{\mathrm{ord}} \ge (e^\beta - 1)^{|E_c|}$ and the fact that $\beta \ge \beta_0$, we obtain
$$
\frac{w_c(F)}{Z_c^{\mathrm{ord}}} \le q^{\eta n/2}(e^\beta - 1)^{-|E_c \setminus F|} \le q^{\eta n/2 - \frac{19}{10d} \frac{9}{10}\eta |E_c|}
$$
With high probability, the number of edges $|E_c|$ is at least $\frac{dn}{2} - 2ne^{-d/3}$, which is greater than or equal to $\frac{dn}{3}$ for all sufficiently large $d$. This leads to the inequality $\frac{w_c(F)}{Z_c^{\mathrm{ord}}} \le q^{\eta n(1/2 - 57/100)}$, which can be further bounded by $q^{-\eta n/10}$. By summing the probabilities over all such configurations, of which there are at most $2^{|E_c|} < 2^{dn}$, we can conclude that for any sufficiently large $q$, we have $\pi_c^{\mathrm{ord}}(B_0) \le e^{-n}$.
